name: Murray, Sen Andrew
text:
—by leave—I move:
(1)	 Clause 2, page 2 (after line 26), after subclause (4), insert:
(4A)	 Part 3 of Schedule 4 is taken to have commenced on 3 May 1998.
(2)	 Schedule 4, page 80 (after line 2), at the end of the schedule, add:
Part 3—Liability for debts or liabilities of a related body corporate
48  After Division 6 of Part 5.7B
Insert:
Division 6A—Liability of a company for the debts or liabilities of a related body corporate
588YA  Liability of a company for the debts or liabilities of a related body corporate
(1)	 On the application of the liquidator of a company that is being wound up in insolvency, the Court may, if it is satisfied that it is just, order that a company that is or has been a related body corporate must pay to the liquidator the whole or part of the amount of a debt or liability of the first-mentioned company that is an admissible claim in the winding up.
(2)	 In deciding whether it is just to make an order under subsection (1), the matters to which the Court must have regard include:
	 (a)	 the extent to which the related body corporate took part in the management of the company;
	 (b)	 the conduct of the related body corporate towards the creditors of the company generally and to the creditor to which the debt or liability relates;
	 (c)	 the extent to which the circumstances that gave rise to the winding up of the company are attributable to the actions of the related body corporate; and
	 (d)	 the extent to which the insolvent company has, at any time, engaged in one or more transactions which have resulted in the value of the insolvent company's assets being reduced; and
	 (e)	 any other relevant matters.
(3)	 An order under this section may be subject to conditions.
(4)	 An order must not be made under this section if the only ground for making the order is that creditors of the company have 
 relied on the fact that another company is or has been a related body corporate of the company.
I am dealing here with what can be broadly referred to as the Patrick amendments. They arise with some urgency because of the requirement that our financial sector, our business sector and, indeed, our employee sector be protected from practices which would otherwise be very dangerous if they were allowed to continue.
You will note that item 1 provides a date by which this is to have commenced, and it refers to the date 3 May. I have followed the practice of the government and of the former Labor government of relating the amendment back to the date of a press release, in case of companies taking advantage of the situation between knowing of such an amendment coming up and the amendment becoming law to exercise what I may refer to as devious practices. That is the significance of the date 3 May 1998.
The substantive amendment is that on item 2, and it refers to the liability for debts or liabilities of a related body corporate. We are concerned here with entities structuring themselves in such a way as to avoid liabilities or responsibilities by interposing companies with little capital backing between creditors, employees and the companies within the group which have substantial assets.
This is not a new problem. In 1988 the Law Reform Commission conducted a general insolvency inquiry. As a part of that inquiry, the commission considered the possibility of making related companies liable for the debts of an insolvent company in certain circumstances, and the commission recommended that companies should be so liable. A draft section D13 was produced. That draft section is a relatively simple one which essentially hands a discretion to a court to order a related company to contribute an amount to the debts of the insolvent company on its winding up.
In its considerations the Law Reform Commission—and for the purposes of Hansard, I am referring to pages 146 and 147 of that report—reported as will follow. I ask for the Senate to bear with me, because I think 
 what they said is worth repeating at length so I will quote all the way through. The quote is as follows:
Liability for debts or liabilities of a related company
334.	Relaxation of separate entity principle . Although this topic of liability for debts or liabilities of related companies does not strictly fall under the heading of director liability and disqualification, it is similar in that it deals with the imposition of liability on persons who have been closely connected with the running of the company but who would ordinarily be protected from being required to contribute to the amount available for distribution in the winding up. Under the existing law, the separate personality of each company prevents access to the funds of one company for the payment of the debts or liabilities of a related company except where the debtor company is a shareholder or creditor of the related company. This may operate unfairly where the business activity of a company has been directed or controlled by a related company. It is as though the related company was acting as a `director' of the other company and causing it to incur debts and liabilities.
335.	Proposal in DP 32 . In DP 32 (para 222) the Commission proposed to give the court a wide discretion to order that a company that is or has been a related company pay to the liquidator all or part of an amount which is an admissible claim in the winding up `if it is satisfied that it is just'. Three specific criteria to which it was proposed the court may have regard were
.	 the extent to which the related company took part in the management of the company
.	 the conduct of the related company towards the creditors of the company and
.	 the extent to which the circumstances that gave rise to the winding up of the company are attributable to the actions of the related company.
It should not, of course, be sufficient that creditors have merely relied on the assets of the related company in their decision to deal with the company.
336. Assessment and recommendation.  The Commission's proposal was supported by several submissions. One submission, from the Law Council of Australia, strongly opposed the proposal on four grounds.
. Separate entity principle.  The Council said that it is a fundamental principle of company law that separate companies have separate legal entities. However, as a matter of policy, the Commission sees no reasonable objection to recommending the imposition of liability where a parent company permits its subsidiary to incur debts when insolvent. 

. Project financing.  The Council argued that financing for large resource and other projects needs to be done on a limited recourse basis, but that, under the Commission's proposal, it would not be possible for a parent company to satisfy itself that it would not be liable for the debts of the project. However, the fact that creditors have entered into contracts on a limited recourse basis would be one of the `other relevant matters' to which the court is required to have regard.
. Uncertainty.  The Council said that the uncertainty in commercial dealings that would be created by the wide discretion given to the court would be undesirable. Lenders would be unable to ascertain the true liabilities of parent companies and could be expected to assume that at least some unguaranteed liabilities of subsidiaries should be taken into account. However, persons lending to the parent of a group of companies have regard not only to its balance sheet but to the consolidated balance sheet of the group and generally take cross-collateralised security. The Commission does not accept therefore that the suggested uncertainty would follow from its proposal. Moreover liability for a subsidiary's debts otherwise than under a guarantee would only arise in the context of the Commission's recommendations  where that subsidiary was or became insolvent.
. Accounts.  The Council suggested that auditors and company directors would have enormous difficulty in producing accounts which represent a true and fair view of a parent company. However, the Commission does not accept that accounting difficulties are sufficiently serious to deter it from recommending the imposition of liability on a parent company which has permitted its subsidiary to trade while insolvent.
Accordingly, the Commission recommends that companies be liable for the debts or liabilities of related companies in the manner set out in D13.
I have quoted at length to make sure that it is clear in the Hansard  what the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission were. It went on in fact to outline, in what it refers as section D13, the way in which this section should be structured. I have stuck as faithfully as I can to the section that the Law Reform Commission laid out, partly because there is no sense in reinventing the wheel but also because it had obviously carefully considered the matters and weighed the manner in which it should be presented.
I say `as carefully as I can' because I have had to add one section. That is the section which is item 2(d) on sheet 1006. That arose because of the following. Senators would be 
 aware that this occurrence has occurred in three specific instances recently in relation to employee entitlements and that is what is known as the Woodlawn, the Cobar and the Patrick examples. Of course the attention, quite rightly, has been focused on the awful consequences of employers evading their responsibilities through structuring their affairs in such a way that they can escape them.
While it is true that the Woodlawn, the Cobar and the Patrick examples all relate to employee entitlements, proposed section 588YA will inure for the benefit of all creditors, including those who have judgment debts against the insolvent company as a result of proceedings taken under sections 51AA, 51AB or 51AC of the Trade Practices Act or the franchising code of conduct or any other of the state based retail tenancy legislation for that matter.
Now you are pricking up your ears and you are saying, `Now he's referring to creditors and, not only is he referring to creditors, he is actually referring to matters that affect small business.' I was alerted to this by a letter I got from an organisation which indicated the real danger. I will quote from that letter but I do not choose to give you the source. The letter said:
I consider that your proposed amendments—
because I had circulated these, as I told you, on 3 May—
may also have a wider application to the recent fair trading package in that franchises and shopping centre owners could establish corporate shells to run various business enterprises. Should a franchisee or a retail tenant in a shopping centre ultimately be successful in court proceedings against a business enterprise concerning unconscionable conduct, an award for damages may not be effective if the entity has no assets or puts itself into voluntary administration. The establishment of such corporate structures would, of course, defeat the fair trading reforms.
Those are important points because, regardless of what your political perspective is, I would be surprised if any senator in any political party would actually relish the thought of companies being able to avoid their obligations to suppliers, banks, landlords, tenants and customers as well as to employees 
 through the restructuring and the deliberate manipulation of their corporate structure to avoid their obligations. I think this kind of legal and accounting spivery should be stamped on by the parliament. It should be stamped on so forcefully that these people will realise that we will not put up with what is immoral and should be illegal.
I do not know why, and I have not inquired into the reasons why, that particular Law Reform Commission recommendation is not yet in law, but I do think it is time we redressed that problem. I would seek, because I do regard it as an urgent matter, the urgent support and the full support of the Senate in stamping this out. It has much reference to recent events, but it really is part of a far broader problem and a far bigger picture. I therefore commend these two amendments to the Senate.

name: Cook, Sen Peter
text:
—The Labor Party will support the Democrat amendments that have just been moved by their spokesman Senator Murray. We emphatically support what he has said; in fact, we are so enthusiastic about it we wish to amend them to make them what is, in our view, stronger. I will come to that in a minute.
Mr Chairman, on the running sheet it appears that the next amendments to be moved are ones by the Labor Party to Senator Murray's amendments. It may expedite the proceedings of the chamber if I were to seek leave to move those amendments now. I notice that Senator Murray has nodded in the affirmative.
Leave granted.
—I move:
(1)	 Subsection 588YA(1), omit "On the application of the liquidator of a company that is being wound up in insolvency,", substitute "On the application of the liquidator or a creditor of a company that is being wound up in insolvency, or on the application of the Commission,".
(2)	 At the end of Schedule 4, Part 3, add:
49  Section 1317HD
	 Repeal the section, substitute: 

1317HD  Recovery of profits, and compensation for loss, resulting from contravention
	 (1)	 Where a person contravenes a civil penalty provision in relation to a corporation, the corporation, a creditor or the Commission may recover from the person, as a debt due to the corporation:
		 (a)	 if that or another person has made a profit because of the act or omission constituting the contravention—an amount equal to the amount of that profit; and
		 (b)	 if the corporation has suffered loss or damage as a result of that act or omission—an amount equal to the amount of that loss or damage;
		 whether or not:
		 (c)	 the first-mentioned person has been convicted of an offence in relation to the contravention; or
		 (d)	 a civil penalty order has been made against the first-mentioned person in relation to the contravention.
	 (2)	 Proceedings under this section may be begun only within 6 years after the contravention.
I wish to speak briefly to Senator Murray's amendments and my amendments to his amendments. In Senator Murray's amendments the words `on the application of the liquidator' appear. The distinctive difference that our amendments seek to bring is to extend that to include as well a creditor of a company and the commission—they are two separate entities. The commission in this case refers to the ASC or, as it will become, the ASIC. The reason I do so is for very much the same reasons as have been very well articulated by Senator Murray. However, I would like to address the Senate on them for a moment so that the position of the Australian Labor Party is very clear.
This amendment is known in my office as the `Patrick amendment' and for good reason. Senator Murray has pointed out that that is a classic and recent case in which a company has stripped its assets from a particular company that engaged employees and returned those assets to the principle company, in this case Lang Corporation, and those employees found themselves to be employed by a company simply as an employee entity without rights to recover their entitlements to pay, 
 annual leave, long service or any other award rights or entitlements that they had.
It was a case that gained national notoriety in the waterfront dispute. It was not, as Senator Murray has said, the only or an isolated example of this sort of behaviour. In Woodlawn and Cobar there were examples of similar practices being engaged to procure the insolvency of a company, drive it into bankruptcy and leave the workers of that company stranded without being able to obtain their rights to pay or other award entitlements. These amendments would close off that type of ability and therefore are desirable in company law. These amendments are also socially desirable and they protect the interests of workers in an employment situation where the artificial arrangement of corporate affairs occurs that creates that end result.
As Senator Murray has said, and I concur, this was not an isolated example; there are others. What is disquieting to me is that, in the midst of the public revelations about how Patrick was asset stripped—once the news broke about how Patrick had confected this artificial concoction—an article appeared in the Australian Financial Review—I do not have it to hand but it is well referenced—which reported that a senior Australian law firm had been inundated by inquiries by various employers about how other companies should do it as well. We have on the record three major corporations in Australia engaging in this practice and by virtue of that article and anecdotal evidence we know that there is interest more widely spread in the corporate community about how this might be done so that they too can take advantage of this issue.
It is therefore appropriate for the parliament to move decisively to close down this type of what can only be described as `employment rort'. Quite apart from the industrial relations elements of this there are other good reasons in corporate law why it should be done.
I want to take the time of the chamber for a few minutes to put down clearly and quite explicitly why these amendments will operate in the way in which I have said and to explain the nature of the scam that was followed in the case of the Patrick company.
The Patrick companies, which employed the labour within the Patrick group—and there were four of them—were stripped of their assets. Most of these assets went upstream to other companies in the Patrick group. The only significant asset left with the Patrick employing companies was a contract to supply labour to the rest of the Patrick group. This has a provision, which the administrators describe in their report as `onerous', which provided that if there were any interruption to the supply of labour by, for example, industrial action, the Patrick group could terminate the labour hire contract and therefore obtain their labour from another source.
These changes in the Patrick corporate structure were made without the knowledge of the work force. That is a significant point. No worker was consulted on this; it happened in secret. They did not know that they were actually employed by companies that were little more than $2 registered companies and they did not know that their contract to supply labour to the Patrick group could be terminated on such easy grounds.
When Patrick terminated their entire work force of 1,400 workers, they relied on this new structure. The Patrick group determined the grounds had been made out to terminate the labour hire contracts with the Patrick employing companies, and these contracts were terminated. The Patrick group was free to hire labour from other sources, which they did; hiring labour from the NFF and P&C Stevedores. At the same time, the Patrick employing companies were placed in receivership, having lost their only significant asset: the contract to supply labour to the Patrick group. The employees of the Patrick labour hire companies were, as a result, basically left without their two most important rights. Any claims to secure entitlements like annual leave, sick pay, redundancy pay and long service leave could only be made against their direct employer, the $2 company—Patrick's employing companies, now in receivership. Their right to be protected against unlawful termination was rendered meaningless.
The workers could only be reinstated to their direct employer, the Patrick employing companies, but those companies were in 
 receivership and, in any event, the Patrick group would be under no obligation to take labour from those companies. A reinstatement is therefore of no practical effect even though it was clear that they were sacked illegally, and that is because they were members of a union.
The government has tried to say that the circumstances of the Patrick corporate scam were unique. That is plain wrong. Any corporate group could organise their structures so that employees are employed by internal labour hire companies with a tenuous agreement to supply labour to the rest of the group. Indeed, many corporate groups, for quite legitimate reasons, already have separate companies within the group and employ the labour just as separate companies own the assets, own the land, hold the debt or hold the tax losses. A corporate group could easily alter this structure so that they could do what Patrick have done.
Any employee who is employed in this sort of structure is effectively without any job security at all. They have a legal entitlement to redundancy pay, long service leave, accrued holiday and sick pay, but that is only enforceable against a company which is only a $2 company. There will be no assets to provide these entitlements on termination. They have a legal right not to be sacked illegally, but any reinstatement order is only enforceable against the direct employer which may not have worked to provide to the employee. That is why the bill introduced in this chamber as a private member's bill by Senator Mackay, and the amendments that I have moved are important.
The Patrick scam could happen to anyone. Any employee could be left without an effective means of being reinstated to their job or getting their accrued legal entitlements. Labor's amendments to the Democrats' amendments here today ensure that this cannot happen again. It gives employees a measure of job security. It does so by making amendments to the Corporations Act.
The two amendments to the Corporations Act are as follows. The first amendment provides, where a company is in receivership, that the court can make an order requiring a 
 related company to pay the debts of the other company, including debts owed to employees like accrued entitlements. The requirements for liability of the related company in this case are also somewhat different. The matters which the court will take into account in determining whether to make an order are as follows: the extent to which the related company took part in the management of the employer; the conduct of the related company towards the creditors of the company generally, and to the creditor to which the debt or liability relates—that is, the employees; the extent to which the circumstances that gave rise to the winding up of the employer are attributable to the actions of the related company; and any other related matters. Again, this provision will give greater security to employees in relation to their accrued legal entitlements.
The second amendment will give creditors the right to bring proceedings for the recovery of debts against directors of companies acting in contravention of the Corporations Law. At present, the only company, usually the liquidator or receiver, has this right. Under this provision, creditors such as employees will be given the right. In the Patricks case it would mean that employees of the Patrick companies, not just the receivers, would have the right to sue Chris Corrigan and other Patrick directors for debts arising from breaches by them of the Corporations Law.
Those are my supporting arguments for the amendments that I moved. We will be supporting the Democrats' amendments. We hope the chamber will support our extension of those amendments.

name: Murray, Sen Andrew
text: —The Democrats will accept the opposition's amendments to our amendment.

name: Campbell, Sen Ian
text:
—I will make some brief comments on these matters. I know they are extremely important to the labour movement. I appreciate the way in which the debate is being handled because the passage of the so-called Wallis package is very important to the government.
Without going into the policy issues at length, the policy issues were, I might say, dealt with by the Harmer report not so long ago; a report that was given to the previous government on these very issues, these subsidiary and insolvency issues, which are directly comparable with Cobar and Woodlawn. The previous government made a decision to come down with the stand that we now have, so they made a deliberate policy decision there. That is not to say that it is not time to review these issues. The Labor Party has made that decision and it may indeed prove to be the right decision.
One of the things that the structure of the Corporations Law in Australia post-1990 requires—particularly these sections of the Corporations Law—is ministerial council approval for any proposal. It was the process that I described during the second reading debate on this package that did indeed delay a number of the amendments that we have considered. Obviously, in a federation the processes where you have ministerial council structures which were put in place by the previous government—and supported by us—ensure that the states get a say in these matters.
Dealing with the amendments in the way that is proposed today will be in breach of the corporations agreement. However, can I say on the constructive side that these matters have already been brought before ministerial council by one of its members—indeed, the Attorney-General for New South Wales, Jeff Shaw, which will be a nice surprise to members opposite—so they will have to be dealt with by the ministerial council. That is the appropriate way for them to be dealt with. I do not intend going into any more detail on the detailed provisions which are the subject of the Democrats'—and now amended by Labor—amendments. The coalition will oppose them and clearly the people in the other place will have to make a decision if the Senate does indeed pass them.

name: Mackay, Sen Sue
text:
—Just to make some additional comments to support those made by Senator Murray and Senator Cook, I go to the private member's bill which is before us, moved in 
 my name in the Senate and in the name of Bob McMullan in the House of Representatives. I would like to say that I agree wholeheartedly with the comments of Senator Murray when he says, `Now is the time to deal with this matter expeditiously.' This is really the first opportunity we have had, since the unfortunate events where 1,400 people were sacked, to attempt some remedial action with regard to this and to attempt, in legislation, to take some action whereby this sort of activity cannot happen again.
I would just like to say that the very day that the 1,400 Patrick workers were sacked we had some very unedifying spectacles, both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. In fact it was quoted by the media as `gloating and gleeful' activity and behaviour from members of the government. I had to speak on it the next day and I found utterly distasteful the sight of anybody at all in Australia, let alone members of the government, let alone ministers of the Crown, taking a clear personal pleasure in the sacking of 1,400 workers.
I have to say that it was a very emotional day for us on this side of the chamber when we spoke about this in great depth the next day. The irony was not lost on me that at the same time as the government was expressing concern for the workers employed at Cobar and the workers employed at Woodlawn, saying this was dreadful, that they did not support it and they would go out of their way to ensure that benefit would flow on and so on—although it took a considerable amount of time for that matter to be sorted out—certain members of the government were clearly involved in or knew of the asset stripping activities of Patrick and were being advised by senior public servants as to how this could happen in terms of the replacement of the Patrick work force with an entirely new work force. So it was a very unedifying spectacle. I think that the government's comments with regard to Cobar and Woodlawn seem in retrospect to be hypocritical in the extreme and it really is not the sort of thing that we want in this country.
I would like to say that if this type of activity had been conducted by a trade union 
 in this country there would have been absolute mayhem on the government benches. There would have been calls for, if not immediate action in relation to, the deregistration of the union that was involved in any activity that was comparable with what Patrick did. This government has come down on unions like a ton of bricks—and so has the ACCC, headed by Allan Fels—where they have regarded them as improper in terms of free flowing business.
We have a situation where the government has let business get away with this. The government has not only let business get away with it, it in fact conspired—this is a case that the government will claim is sub judice and we will have an argument about that in the next few weeks—to ensure that this could happen. So it has not simply been passive, simply doing nothing, it has been proactively working with a company to ensure that this could happen.
This, in modern day Australia, is absolutely outrageous. But, it does not stop there. We also have a situation—and I would like to talk to the Senate about this—whereby this type of practice has in fact been replicated in one of the government's own agencies. I refer here to Employment National. The minister owns eight out of the 10 shares of Employment National. When the Employment Security Bill 1998  was introduced into the Senate it was very clear that the government at that point intended to ensure that the jobs of the CES workers would be transferred into the new Employment National with the usual rights with regard to long service leave and using the GECA award in terms of the no disadvantage test.
What happened was that the opposition and the Democrats were successful in moving a number of amendments with regard to that bill. What happened? Senator Vanstone pulled the bill and we have not seen it since. We have only to look at the consequences of that attempt to institute the types of changes that were incumbent within that bill, but without legislation, to see that has created a whole series of problems for the government that are coming to light now.
But the critical thing with regard to those CES workers who have lost their jobs with the abolition of the CES is that they were under the clear understanding in terms of the whole process that they would be given the option, first, of voluntary redundancy—which is fair enough; that is an accepted public sector practice—or, second, transferral to the new Employment National. In relation to what conditions they would be employed under in the new Employment National, we had a discussion at the estimates round before last with the employment advocate as to what he would use in order to ensure the no disadvantage test was properly applied.
Prior to the employment advocate's appearing at estimates, workplace relations officials had advised the Senate committee that the GECA award would not be used with regard to the application of the no disadvantage test, that there was no relevant award because Employment National was a new company. When the employment advocate appeared in front of the Senate estimates committee, we asked him what he would be using. He said that, quite clearly, the GECA award was the appropriate benchmark to use with regard to the application of the no disadvantage test. So the government and Employment National were caught between a rock and a hard place with regard to ensuring that these people did not experience any diminution of their conditions.
What happened subsequent to that? Employment National set up a labour hire company; that is what happened. So you have got Employment National operating and you have got an Employment National labour hire company. Now Employment National, the government owned organisation for the delivery of employment services in this country, is saying, `Sorry, we don't employ the CES workers. We don't directly employ anybody. It is the labour hire company that employs them.' Therefore, there is no direct nexus between the GECA award and the conditions of the CES workers and the people who are going to be picked up by Employment National. They will be employed by this other company.
There is a personnel link between Employment National and Patrick. I am not suggesting that this necessarily has any genuine significance, and I do not intend to cast aspersions on this person at this stage, but Peter Storey, who heads Employment National, used to work for Patrick. With regard to the changes that Employment National is currently going through—and has been taken to court on by the union, incidentally—there seems to have been a change of tactic when Mr Storey came on the scene. I am not sure whether that is coincidence or whether it is, in fact, premeditated. It is the matter of a court case at the moment and it is something about which we will have to wait and see.
But the reality is that those CES workers who have been offered employment with Employment National have been told that to get that employment they have to sign an AWA or they will not get the job. These are CES people who are employed under the Public Service Act and whose conditions were determined by GECA. They have been told that, in order to secure any future employment whatsoever, they are going to be forced to sign an AWA, to their own severe disadvantage with regard to the diminution of their wages and conditions.
So it is not simply in the corporate sector that this is happening. It is simply not good enough for the government to come along here and cry crocodile tears about the Cobar workers and the Woodlawn workers. The Employment National situation is happening in the government's own backyard, with the complicity and the full knowledge of the government, in a company owned by the government. If we cannot trust the government owned enterprises not to do this, how on earth can we have any confidence with regard to the corporate sector? That is the point. It is all very well for the parliamentary secretary to come in and say, `This is a matter that needs to go to ministerial council' or whatever, and `Yes, there may be some merit in this.'
I say to the government that if it genuinely has a concern about what happened to the workers at Cobar and Woodlawn—and we know the government does not have any 
 concern for what happened to the workers at Patrick Stevedores—then why not do something about fixing up what is happening in its own backyard with regard to Employment National? Let us ensure that there is a proper corporate structure with Employment National. Let us ensure that the ex-CES workers, or whoever, are in fact employed directly by Employment National, not by a labour hire company which allows Employment National to deliberately get out of commitments that it otherwise would have with the transfer of people from the public sector.
I say to the government that not only is it grossly hypocritical not to support the amendments moved by Senator Murray and Senator Cook with respect to the corporate sector, but also it is being grossly hypocritical in terms of the corporate structure of Employment National. If the government chooses not to support—and clearly the parliamentary secretary has indicated that it will not—the amendments moved by Senator Murray and Senator Cook, at least it should do something about what is happening now in its own backyard with Employment National.
Returning to the substance of the amendments that are attempting to provide security for Australian workers, I am very distressed to hear—I did not see the article that Senator Cook alluded to in the Financial Review—that a law firm has been inundated with requests. This is something that has to be actioned now. This is something that cannot wait for a time whereby it is convenient for the government to deal with it. In terms of what Senator Cook advised the Senate, clearly this type of behaviour is happening right throughout Australia in the corporate sector.
What are we going to do? Are we going to wait until there is a plethora of Patrick style labour hire companies all over the country—or Employment National style labour hire companies—so that we have a repetition of a Cobar situation, a Woodlawn situation or a Patrick situation, before we act? Is that what the government is seriously asking us to do? Or can we do what Senator Cook and Senator Murray are proposing and carry these amendments now to ensure that such activity is clearly not legal?
We have in front of us four examples of where this type of activity has occurred: Cobar, Woodlawn, Patrick and Employment National. The latter two—there is absolutely no doubt in anybody's mind—knew precisely what they were doing. They deliberately used provisions in order to ensure they were able to, in the Patrick case, sack an entire work force—illegally, as it transpired, although it was clearly illegal to us at the time—and in Employment National's case to ensure that it can shed and shirk its responsibilities to workers who will be employed by it.
I say to the government: let us not wait for several years for more and more of these companies to go bust and not allow their workers their due entitlements. Let us do something about it now by ensuring that this sort of situation does not happen in the future. I reiterate that if the government is genuinely concerned about this type of corporate structure one of the first things it should do is fix up its own backyard and do something about Employment National.

name: Cooney, Sen Barney
text:
—This amendment deserves to be supported. It is a pity that such an amendment has to be suggested. There is always a danger of romanticising one's youth, but in my days—if I can use that expression—people were not inclined to ask if something was legal in the way that the people advising Patrick may have asked, but the question was: did it pass the smell test? What was meant by the smell test was that it might be legal, but, if it was not ethical, honourable or fair, then you should not do it.
One gets the feeling that those who advised Patrick planned and plotted a course for it to take. It is perhaps the most dramatic example, but by no means the only example, of lawyers advising at the insistence of their client—and perhaps suggesting to their client in some cases—how they can construct things so as to avoid their real moral obligations.
Senator Murray has—no doubt with some regret—had to move this amendment. On many occasions he has spoken on corporate law in this chamber, and in his practice in that field he certainly would not have done anything that did not pass the smell test. It 
 has not only occurred in Patrick's case, or in the examples given by Senator Mackay in her excellent speech, but it has also occurred in the meat industry where again and again abattoirs have closed down and left people unpaid.
Within company law there is that proposition that directors owe a duty to the company and to the company only. There was the old case of Foss v. Harbottle in about 1843.
—You will have to explain that one to me.
—The senator would know that case, no doubt. There has been a movement away from that. In legislation we are about to consider, the Company Law Review Bill 1997, the government has seen the virtue of moving away from the Foss v. Harbottle decision, because it says:
A company's legal capacity to do something is not affected by the fact that the company's interests are not, and would not be, served by doing it.
That suggests that the government understands the need to counter situations such as that presented by the Patrick case. 	 Although those who are advising Patrick might say it is in the company's interests to do what it did, nevertheless there are wider obligations that they should attend to. Indeed, its reputation would be much better had it acted differently, and had it and many other companies not made necessary the amendments put forward by Senator Murray.
Senator Ian Campbell said quite rightly that this is a national scheme and there are problems caused by that. I do not think that should stop us progressing this and expressing our opinion that this is a matter that needs to be dealt with rapidly.
I will quote a passage from the classic work on corporations, The Modern Corporation and Private Property. No doubt this has been read by members of the chamber. It was written by Berle and Means. It was first issued in 1932, so it has been around for a while. I will quote this passage:
Corporations have ceased to be merely legal devices through which the private business transactions of individuals may be carried on. Though still much used for this purpose, the corporate form has acquired a larger significance. The corporation has, 
 in fact, become both a method of property tenure and a means of organising economic life. Grown to tremendous proportions—
and this is in 1932—
there may said to have evolved a `corporate system'—as there was once a feudal system—which has attracted to itself a combination of attributes and powers, and has attained a degree of prominence entitling it to be dealt with as a major social institution.
The phrase that there is now a corporate system as there was once a feudal system is a very powerful one. This was written well over 60 years ago and the position has got even worse. Large corporations do control their workers—and I use the word `control' advisedly—as if this was a feudal system. It was a feudal action in the most dramatic of cases, that is, the Patrick case, but this feudal system is the system that corporations use in many situations.
While taking on board what Senator Ian Campbell said, I think that the present situation needs to be remedied and needs to be remedied quickly. Senator Cook and Senator Murray have put forward a most timely amendment.

name: Conroy, Sen Stephen
text:
—I wish to follow up the contributions from Senator Cooney and Senator Mackay. Not that long ago the Cobar and Woodlawn workers were camped on the lawns outside Parliament House. They had a sad and sorry story to tell about how corporate spivvery had taken hundreds and thousands of dollars of their own entitlements. It was nothing special: nothing more than their long-service leave; nothing more than their accrued holidays; and nothing more than their superannuation.
By a little bit of corporate spivvery, a bit of asset stripping, they had been left with nothing. I think there might have been $9 million in the case of one. For many days the government refused to even acknowledge their presence on the lawns. They were sad days for Australia. After some media attention and persistence from the workers, who were not prepared to be ignored, eventually a delegation got to meet with the Prime Minister. He promised not a great deal to give them hope, but at least he listened. He talked about reviewing the situation.
A few weeks later we saw Patrick Stevedores move in with the dogs and the balaclavas, and it became clear that the Prime Minister—as on the GST when he said `never ever'—really was crying crocodile tears with those workers. We have seen a similar situation—as Senator Mackay has so eloquently outlined—with Employment National. Here is a government that wants you to believe it cares, that wants you to believe that it is for the battlers, that wants you to believe that it is prepared to make sure that workers' entitlements are protected, that promised Australian workers before the last election that nobody would be worse off. Well, there are a few workers at Cobar, Woodlawn, Employment National and, more importantly, at Patrick, who have been made a heck of a lot worse off. You could almost be forgiving of it, if it were simply the corporates doing this but, as Senator Mackay said, the government has been doing it itself. So when it says to the workers that the Prime Minister met with, `We are looking at it', it is true that it has been looking at the issue but it has been looking at how to refine it and do it better.
We have seen the government willing to spend taxpayers' money in a guarantee to Patrick to get them to sack the entire union work force. This was the end of real job security. A lot of battlers in Australia are worried. You do not have a job for life any more. Many organisations, both public and private, do not have a culture any more of `You start work here when you are 18, you finish when you are 65, and you work for the one company all your life.' That is a thing of the past. In the last election campaign the Prime Minister promised workers that they would have job security, and he gave them every indication that he was willing to have a look at these sorts of issues. Today is the `put up or shut up' test. Today the government can accept the Labor Party's amendments and put into action right here what it told those Cobar and Woodlawn workers it was prepared to look at.
I say to Senator Campbell—through you, Madam Temporary Chairman—that we accept that the states have a role to play, that this is a federation. But what you are seeing, report 
 ed in the Financial Review, as Senator Cook has mentioned, is a flood of interest in copying these proposals, this legal spivvery that has taken away ordinary workers' conditions and rights. Yes, we do need support from the states, but we need leadership from the federal government—something that is lacking in a lot of different areas. Here is the chance to strike a blow for the battlers. Here is a chance to say, `We accept that this sort of corporate chicanery cannot go on.'
The angst felt by those families can be redressed in a small way. There is not a lot this legislation can do for those it has already happened to—I do not believe we are proposing a retrospectivity aspect to it. Here is a chance to make sure that it cannot happen again because, if you, as members of the government, reject this amendment, every time it happens it is on your head. You have the capacity to accept this amendment and put pressure on the states, as you do in any set of circumstances. But each time another worker appears in the newspaper or on A Current Affair or anywhere else and they have had their super, their leave loading or their long service entitlements taken—because a company has been involved in asset stripping or has established the mechanisms to take from their workers what is not theirs to take—it is on your head if you reject these amendments.
You cannot cry the crocodile tears you cried a few weeks ago over Cobar and Woodlawn. At the time I thought it was pretty funny that the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, and John Sharp and others took up the case on behalf of some of those workers. They were prepared to stand up publicly and support them. But at the same time, Mr Sharp, when he was Minister for Transport and Regional Development, was setting this in motion. Peter Reith cried crocodile tears about the workers—how he would be willing to look at it and how it was terrible that it had happened—and all the time they were working away behind the scenes to take away workers' rights.
I would like to talk about the smell test that Senator Cooney discussed. The government set itself up to work with Patrick—that is, Chris Corrigan and Peter Scanlon. The latter 
 is an old favourite of mine. I have spoken quite often  now on Peter Scanlon and his role through the 1980s in two of the biggest six corporate scams that have ever taken place. That is not something I have alleged; that was said by the National Companies and Securities Commission, which went on to become the ASC, the corporate watchdog. They said, `These are the big six scams that happened in the 1980s. These are the real spivvy performances'. And Peter Scanlon was up to his neck in two of them.
I will not spend too much time on the Elders H fee, Swiss bonds and VicInvest, to name but three of the transactions that Elders was involved in, that Peter Scanlon was the corporate brains behind.	John Elliott gets a lot of the publicity because he is larger than life. But the real brains, the corporate strategist, behind what went on at Elders was Peter Scanlon. He would not pass Senator Cooney's smell test in a million years. Yet this government decided it was going to get into bed with one of the biggest corporate spivs in this country when it decided to back Corrigan and Scanlon.
I have talked before about the whole corporate scam behind the Swiss bonds. That is still under investigation by the National Crime Authority. It is not dead, it is not buried, as much as Corrigan wants to say, `It's something from the past; it's nothing to do with me.'
Scanlon wanted to settle his case with the NCA to try and pretend he had a win. He paid costs. The big test when it comes to a settlement in a legal action is who pays the costs. Peter Scanlon paid the NCA's costs. He got out and left John Elliott in this case by himself. He can say what he likes afterwards, but he knew that he was going to lose that case because it was an absolute scam. He was trying to pretend the NCA prosecuted him, chased him, defamed him and lowered his standing in the community, causing him to claim $200 million worth of damages.
Three of the four original claimants in that case have now bailed out and paid the NCA's costs. There is just big John left, and he will go down, too. He will be up for an awful lot of costs when that is all settled. But that is a 
 matter before the courts and I do not want to canvass it too widely. I simply make the point again that Scanlon pulled the pin, paid the costs of the NCA, and got out.
All the time that was happening, what was the government doing? It was having secret meetings with this company—establishing itself, setting itself up to take ordinary workers' superannuation, ordinary workers' leave loading and long service leave—and with this same man. It was setting itself up to move in with the dogs on the chains and the people in balaclavas.
How would you feel if you were one of those Townsville wharfies who were acknowledged by the Prime Minister on A Current Affair as meeting world's best practice? There is no dispute. Neither the government, Scanlon nor Corrigan has tried to say that, up in Townsville, the workers were involved in anything other than world's best practice. Yet they had to be sacked as well. The Prime Minister admitted on national television, `Well, there'll be a few casualties along the way on the glorious road to reform.' They were sacked because they were union members; they lost their entitlements because they were union members, and this government was in it up to its neck.
I read with interest in this morning's papers that Justice North rejected the government's claims that it would be just too hard now to hold the court case into this and that it should be put off until the end of the year. Justice North said that the court case will go on. So we all look forward to the revelations. We all look forward to seeing a number of senior government ministers in the dock providing the documents that they will not give this Senate. They have now rejected the Democrats' and the opposition's attempts to get hold of the documents that will show how complicit they were.
Two weeks ago we even had the revelation in the Financial Review that the government, following a request to do so, provided a document and said, `This is it; this is what you asked for.' Then we find out from the Financial Review that they blanked out the last line and the attachment because the last line said, `Refer to the structure in the attach 
 ment.' What is that if not misleading the Senate? They are prepared to do anything to hide their involvement in this.
So it will come as no surprise when they reject our amendments, Senator Murray, because they have been in it up to their necks. They are in a situation where they could go to the state legal officers, the attorneys-general, and say, `We need this to protect battlers.' They could go to Queensland and say, `Here's your chance, Rob Borbidge; here's your chance, Joan Sheldon. You can support the battlers in your state; you can protect Townsville workers'—
—And small business.
—And small business—absolutely, Senator Murray. They could say, `You can be part of protecting all of those. You can use this in your state election. This will be a big winner for you, and it will dovetail in with our strategy about the battlers. But don't mention the GST; talk about the battlers instead.' 
So the smell test should have been applied to Patrick, it should have been applied to Corrigan, and it should have been applied to Scanlon, because there is no way anybody who is reputable in the financial community would deal with Scanlon and Elliott any more. Those are the facts if you go and talk with the business community around Australia. They know they smell; they know what really went on. But this government decided, for their own grubby ends, that the ends justified the means. They were prepared to look the other way, and—worse—they were prepared to deceive this parliament consistently for 12 months while they set up this corporate scam. Today is the day of reckoning. Today you can accept the amendments that will stop this sort of asset stripping and the taking of workers' legal entitlements away from them.
Amendments (by Senator Cook) agreed to.
Amendments (by Senator Murray), as amended, agreed to.

name: Murray, Sen Andrew
text:
—by leave—I move:
(1)	 Schedule 1, page 7 (after line 27), after item 8, insert: 

8A  After subsection 9(3)
Insert:
	 (3AA)	 At least one member must be a consumer representative.
	 (3AB)	 The Minister shall nominate a person as a member under subsection (3AA) only if the Minister is satisfied that the person has, as a substantial part of his or her recent work, been a consumer representative or advocate in the financial services industry or a related industry.
(2)	 Schedule 1, page 8 (after line 1), after item 9, insert:
9A Subsection 9(4)
Omit "The", substitute "Subject to subsections (3AA) and (3AB), the".
(3)	 Schedule 14, item 48, page 162 (line 19), at the end of paragraph (d), add ", at least one of whom must be a consumer representative".
(4)	 Schedule 14, item 48, page 163 (after line 9), after subsection 25B(3), insert:
(3A)	 The Governor-General must not appoint a person as a consumer representative member unless the Governor-General is satisfied that the person has, as a substantial part of his or her recent work, been a consumer representative or advocate in the financial services industry or a related industry.
These amendments refer to the Financial Sector Reform (Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1998 . I have outlined in my speech at the second reading stage the need for strong consumer protection in the financial services industry, a sentiment echoed in other speeches in the second reading debate. Most of our discussion on this will be under the Financial Sector Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1998, which we will be considering after this one.
Satisfactory consumer protection will not be achieved simply by legislating for codes of conduct and dispute resolution processes. We also need to ensure that policy settings and the operations of key regulators are also guided by consumer considerations. Amendments 1 and 2 provide that the membership of the Payment System Board includes a member with a consumer representation or advocacy background. The Payment System Board will be replacing some of the functions of the Australian Payment System Council. The 
 board will retain the payment system monitoring and public reporting functions of the APSC. Consumer representatives have contributed greatly to its operation. The need for consumer representation in this area continues, as the advent of new technologies greatly increases the complexity of participation in the payment systems and broadens the issues.
Amendments 3 and 4 refer to the need for consumer expertise within the new Australian Securities and Investments Commission. That is paramount now that ASIC is to be solely responsible for financial sector consumer protection. It will be vital that there is the necessary experience and understanding of consumer protection issues at the top executive level as the transition is made from the ASC to the vastly expanded ASIC. Such guidance will help establish the new vision for ASIC: the new structures, the new culture and the new operational approaches.
We are therefore moving to ensure that a commissioner is appointed to the ASIC who has consumer protection experience. We are encouraged by the work on measures for the `good advice' policy program. The government may argue that the ASC already has such a person at commissioner level. If that is so, it does not militate against our amendment, because there is no requirement for such a person at this stage. What we are seeking is a requirement for there to be such a person.
Our eye was also drawn to the Financial Sector Advisory Council. This council has some very eminent Australian business people drawn from the financial sector. They are doubtless very well placed to discuss the impact of the post- Wallis changes, or what will be post-Wallis after today, on finance sector companies. The council seems less well placed to discuss the impacts of those reforms on customers. Businesses, of course, are always concerned with customers because that is where they make their profit, but they may not view customers in the way that we would expect a customer representative to view customers. This is a poignant concern because of the fact that the council will be responsible for an evaluation of the reforms in five years, 
 so we are looking for a particular perspective. The council is non-statutory, so the Australian Democrats are not seeking legislative measures there but do seek action by the Treasurer and Assistant Treasurer, and indeed by the Parliamentary Secretary, to redress this imbalance.

name: Campbell, Sen Ian
text:
—The Democrat amendments propose that at least one member of ASIC and the Payment System Board should be a consumer representative. As senators would know, there are currently three commissioners of the ASC, including the chairman. They operate on a full-time basis and do not act as representatives of any sectional interest. They are appointed on the basis of their standing and their expertise. It is undesirable to appoint representatives of consumers, or any other interests, for that matter, as managers of a regulatory authority with the enforcement responsibilities of the ASIC. This could lead to regulatory capture.
At the moment all three ASC commissioners seek to pursue consumer interests and, if you change the dynamics of this by making one of them a representative of consumers, you may risk issues been decided through an effective voting process. It can also lead to calls by each sectional interest for equivalent representation. ASC commissioners currently and deliberately are required to sever all ties with their previous employer to avoid any potential or perceived conflicts of interest. The ASC already has in place extensive consultative mechanisms to ensure input from all relevant interest groups, including consumer representatives. I might say that I know the liaison that occurs between the ASC and consumer groups is extremely active, if not on a daily basis.
ASIC will continue to work closely with consumer interests to help it understand fully and to take proper account of consumer needs in policy development and to make it aware at an early stage of problems which consumers are experiencing in the financial services sector. Those comments apply equally to the Payment System Council. I might also say that the government's proposed amendments 
 to the ASC's mission statement make it quite clear that the interests of consumers and the role in the ASC of protecting the interests of consumers are paramount. In particular, if you look at the FSI (Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 1998 it says:
In performing its functions and exercising its powers, the ASIC must strive to promote the confident and informed participation of investors and consumers in the financial system.
We believe that this is a clear signal—in fact, a legislative responsibility—placed on commissioners to act on behalf of consumers. It means you have actually got three commissioners acting on behalf of consumers and not just one. The government will oppose this amendment.

name: Cook, Sen Peter
text:
—This amendment, as described, would prescribe that a commissioner must be exclusively a consumer representative. The opposition, of course, is sympathetic to what is being put here. We think this is quite an important point, but we balance against it the fact that, if sectional interests were given prominence in a bill such as this, there could and would be arguments that other sectional interests should be represented among the commissioners too.
I think, to some extent, whether the commissioners wanted to or not, it would have the effect of creating an expectation that a consumer commissioner would be responsible for consumer matters while they, while embracing consumer matters, might direct their attention to other things as well. The obligation here is that all commissioners should have regard for the consumer interests that this body will deal with. For those reasons, we will not be supporting the amendment.
However, as I said at the beginning, this is quite a serious matter because this is an area in which there have been good examples of why there ought to be a duty of responsibility to their consumers for the financial institutions involved here. There are notorious examples of where consumers have not fared well, to put it mildly, at the hands of banks or other financial institutions.
I am interested to hear that the government regards this to be of paramount importance; it is important for us to hear that. We regard it as of paramount importance as well. It is my intention, while not supporting the Democrats' position at this point, to indeed monitor the performance and developments of this part of the bill should it become law. Of course, if it does not operate in the way in which the concept has been explained in the bill, in the explanatory memorandum and in the discussions that we have had with the government, we would then reserve the right to come back, reopen this bill and insert the amendment that has been proposed.
With those words—I have to call you Mr Chairman, I do not know why standing orders require me to do that, Madam Chairman; but they do, I am informed—perhaps I can seek an assurance from the parliamentary secretary on this point. The particular point that I seek an assurance on, and invite the parliamentary secretary to provide more comment about, is the selection and background of the commissioners.
Senator Murray has raised a question about a consumer representative. We are joining the government in resisting that amendment for the reasons that we jointly share, which I have now articulated and which was referred to earlier. The opposition and the government have both gone on the record now, in Hansard, as saying that we regard consumer protection as paramount.
It is our view that, under this legislation, all commissioners should be responsible for consumer matters. The selection of the commissioners is important and their background and grasp of consumer issues is important. If all of them are responsible, but if all of them are drawn from the corporate sector and are articulate in corporate affairs but not as sensitive to consumer affairs, irrespective of the delegation of responsibility for consumer interests, their background and comprehension of those interests may be limited.
In the selection of these commissioners, I think it is important that the people who are considered have a genuine understanding of the consumer field, or can bridge both the corporate and the consumer fields. Otherwise, 
 with the best will in the world, people will conscientiously turn their attention to a consideration of consumer issues, but if their background does not equip them to comprehend that fully, you will get an in-built bias in the structure of the commission and, thus, I think, less sensitivity to these concerns than the government, the opposition and the Australian Democrats would require. I wonder, Parliamentary Secretary, whether you wish to comment on that?

name: Campbell, Sen Ian
text:
—Under subsection 9(4) of the Australian Securities Commission Act, which will become the ASIC act hopefully at some stage this afternoon or when the Governor-General signs it, the minister nominates a person to be what they call a member of the Australian Securities Commission. Clearly, with the redefinition of the functions which put consumer interests as equal to the interests of investors, he will be required to make appointments keeping in mind those functions and responsibilities. He is required to be satisfied that the person is qualified for appointment by virtue of his or her knowledge of, or experience in, a number of fields which are set out: business, the administration of companies, financial markets, law, economics and accounting.
I think any people in the consumer movement who have had contact with the existing commissioners—Alan Cameron, who was appointed by the previous government and just reappointed by us; Jillian Segal, the newly appointed commissioner; and Peter Day—would know that they are all highly qualified to carry out their functions in relation to consumer protection. I do not think that would ever be an issue. Clearly, the Treasurer will be required to make appointments based on those functions.

name: Cooney, Sen Barney
text:
—I agree with Senator Cook and Senator Campbell that people of top ability should be put on this body. But I think Senator Murray makes a good point, that when governments of both colours look to appointments, they do tend to look at people who practise in corporate law, in constitutional law—in what is 
 called the more `glamorous' part of the law—and at people from other parts of society, whether they come from the corporate world or otherwise, from what is generally called `the big end of town'.
There is an inference in that that the people who practise in community law, environmental law or consumer protection law are somehow not as good as those who practise in other areas or as people in senior corporate positions. That has not been said by Senator Campbell, but I take this opportunity nevertheless to make the point that oftentimes people who practise what is generally called poverty law or environmental law are overlooked when it is wrong for them to be overlooked. There are outstanding practitioners in the areas that I have mentioned. It is a pity that they are overlooked.
Amendments not agreed to.

name: Cook, Sen Peter
text:
—by leave—I move:
(1)	 Schedule 19, page 225 (after line 17), after the definition of  ASIC , insert:
 ISC employee  means a member of the staff assisting the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.
(2)	 Schedule 19, page 225 (line 18), after "subitem 25(1)", insert "or subitem 25(3), as the case requires".
(3)	 Schedule 19, page 226 (lines 7 and 8), omit the note.
(4)	 Schedule 19, page 226 (after line 9), at the end of item 25, add:
(3)	 An ISC employee may, at a particular time (the  person's transfer time ), become an APRA employee because of a declaration under section 81C of the Public Service Act 1922 .
Note about Schedule 19, item 25:	 The heading to item 25 (page 225, line 25) is altered by adding at the end "and the ISC ".
(5)	 Schedule 19, page 226 (line 12), omit "because of item 25", substitute "as mentioned in subitem 25(1) or (3)".
(6)	 Schedule 19, page 226 (line 19), after "RBA employee", insert "or an ISC employee".
(7)	 Schedule 19, page 226 (line 24), after "RBA employee", insert "or an ISC employee".
(8)	 Schedule 19, page 226 (line 26), after "RBA employee", insert "or an ISC employee". 

(9)	 Schedule 19, page 227 (line 3), omit "under item 25", substitute "as mentioned in subitem 25(1) or (3)".
(10)	 Schedule 19, page 227 (line 4), after "Reserve Bank", insert "or the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, as the case requires,".
(11)	 Schedule 19, page 227 (line 9), after "Reserve Bank", insert "or the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner".
Labor's amendments seek to protect Australian Public Service employees transferring to APRA—namely, the 370-odd Insurance Superannuation Commission employees. Schedule 19, items 26 and 27, dealing with terms and conditions of transferred staff and accrued benefits of staff transferring across to the new authority, refer specifically and exclusively to Reserve Bank employees. No reference is made to ISC employees. ISC employees have no legislative grounding to maintain their current terms and conditions of employment or recruit entitlements. Our amendments simply include ISC employees wherever Reserve Bank of Australia employees are mentioned. They ensure that the same guarantees that are given to one set of employees—the RBA employees—are given to all.
To return to 170MB of the Workplace Relations Act, the government originally said that these amendments were not necessary as ISC employees are covered by section 170MB of the Workplace Relations Act 1996, whereas Reserve Bank of Australia employees are not, which is why they need mention in the APRA legislation.
The first point to make is that 170MB covers only certified agreements; it does not cover accrued entitlements or other conditions that APS employees may currently hold, and our amendments would guarantee that. The second issue is that the government has since acknowledged in writing that, because the ISC certified agreement refers to the Public Service Act, technically section 170MB would not apply. I have a letter here which I intend to seek leave to table. I have not shown this to the parliamentary secretary yet. I am happy to defer the seeking of leave until such time as he has had a look at it.
The Treasurer's office first offered to read a statement outlining their commitment to preserve Australian Public Service conditions into Hansard during this debate. While welcome, this was not acceptable to the opposition as sufficient safeguard for the employees. It remains our position that these commitments should be enacted. The government then agreed to go away and come up with suitable amendments—amendments that are now being moved on behalf of the opposition. For whatever reason, they are not prepared to move these amendments themselves.
I note that these amendments are a revised version. They reflect the consultations we have had with the government and limit the cover to ISC employees rather than the broad definition of APS employees. This is a result of the government's written assurances that only ISC employees will be affected in the transfer to the new authority. I have another letter which I have not yet shown to the parliamentary secretary. I intend to seek leave to table that letter as well.
The APS employees are transferred under section 18(c) of the Public Service Act 1922. It allows the Commonwealth authority to `determine any special terms or conditions of employment that are to apply to the persons.' This gives APRA the power to preserve the conditions of employment previously held by APS employees. It also gives them the power to disregard such conditions. A further point should be made about section 81(c). Section 81(c) only comes into effect upon transfer. Only once transferred can the board grant special terms and conditions to staff. This does not give staff any certainty in the interim period. Because APRA does not currently exist, any agreements on conditions, remuneration and entitlements would be subject to approval by the APRA board when established.
Our amendments give guarantees to staff, irrespective of whether or not they have yet been transferred, that the conditions the board determines are no less favourable than those that they would currently hold. I acknowledge that both the Treasurer and the APRA chief executive officer designate, Graeme Thompson, have indicated that most current 
 Public Service conditions will be maintained, although the Treasurer has qualified this by saying that they will be `largely maintained'.
At this stage the government has not made any detailed commitments to staff. On that point, I would remind the Senate that the government does have form on reneging on commitments given to Australian Public Service employees transferring to newly established agencies or authorities. Previous commitments made to the Commonwealth Employment Service staff transferring to Employment National were not honoured when this government set about establishing Employment National through the backdoor.
Without going into that issue, I think it is clear that our amendments would prevent even the possibility of a similar situation occurring here. If the government really is committed to preserving the conditions currently held by ISC employees, then our amendments only ask it to put its money where its mouth is and enact the informal commitments already given.
Finally, I say that the government has also said that our amendments are duplicitous, creating nothing more than pages of extra legislation. We reject this assertion on two fronts. Firstly, we believe that our amendments enshrining in legislation the government's commitments are the best way of ensuring that ISC employees be transferred across to APRA, retaining conditions of employment that are no less favourable than those they currently hold. Secondly, our amendments, far from adding pages of legislation to this omnibus bill, add no more than a few lines.
We believe that the legislation should be explicit for all employees, not just Reserve Bank of Australia employees. Our amendments are simple and brief, but they do deliver certainty to ISC employees transferring to the authority.
—Senator Cook, you sought leave to table two letters. For the first letter, which is addressed to Mr Tom Wheelwright, leave is granted. For the second letter, of which I do not have a copy, leave is not granted. 
—Leave is not granted?
—Leave may be granted, but we just thought it would be a courtesy to ask Mr Thompson first.

—On this issue I will be brief, because we would love to get this finished by quarter to four today. The government believes that these amendments do not need to be included in the legislation, because section 81C of the Public Service Act 1922 provides the mechanism to move APS staff from the APS to a Commonwealth authority, and it enables the APRA board to determine any special terms and conditions of employment to apply to transferring staff.
The legislation was drafted to cover the transfer of RBA staff because they cannot be moved to APRA without specific enabling legislation. The APRA chief executive officer and chairman elect have stated, pending harmonisation of workplace terms and conditions, that they intend to apply the terms and conditions of the ISC certified agreement to ISC transferees with only those amendments as are necessary consequent upon the staff ceasing to be the APS.
Madam Chairman, because we can see that the numbers are clearly here for these amendments, we will not be calling a division on this matter. We will, however, be voting no. That, we believe, is in the interests of the expedient handling of the legislation.
